`<ng-content>` is a special element that accepts markup or a template fragment and controls how components render content. It does not render a real DOM element.

Here is an example of a `BaseButton` component that accepts any markup from its parent.

```
      // ./base-button/base-button.component.tsimport { Component } from '@angular/core';@Component({  selector: 'button[baseButton]',  template: `      <ng-content />  `,})export class BaseButton {}

```

check

```
      // ./app.component.tsimport { Component } from '@angular/core';import { BaseButton } from './base-button/base-button.component.ts';@Component({  selector: 'app-root',  imports: [BaseButton],  template: `    <button baseButton>      Next <span class="icon arrow-right" />    </button>  `,})export class AppComponent {}

```

check

For more detail, check out the [`<ng-content>` in-depth guide](https://angular.dev/guide/components/content-projection) for other ways you can leverage this pattern.
